addressleaf.section:
Considerations uppon those notes w
ch
were sent unto me by
e
LL. of
e councell
, as touching
e explanac
o
n of
e contract &c.

fol.174r
Belgia: 1590. May
Belgia 1590 June
5. It would be an occasion,
at they will geve
no intertenment to any of
her Ma
ties
subjectes:
and besides it would [minister make] of discon-
tentm
t
and mutinie to
other
suche
those [.]
other
souldiers as
are in their pay.
6. The order of
e contrey is a great deale
more favorable, wherby it is permitted
t
all kinde of victuall brought to any camp
shalbe free of Impost and Accise: wheras
the Garrison townes have no suche privilege at
all.
7. Her Ma
ties
subjectes in their marching are no
worse intertened then
e souldiers of
e contrey
who are seldome admitted into close townes:
nether will
e Burgeses be persuaded unto it
but in time of necessitie of taking Garrison.
But
Howbeit
being orderly conducted by
e Comissaries
they are usually billetted in
e villages, and
seeldome in any churche, unles
it be in places
where houses are
scant, and
e multitude great
8. It was never
practised
otherwise.
thought meete that any c
o
panies
should be assigned speciall placs of Garrison: but retur-
ning fr
o
e camp or other service,
suche places
they
were
alwaies
appointed
to
to [those] places
at
t
were
judged
fittest
places w
ch
and those in like maner
for
sundrie good respectes wee are often times changed.
11. Then the resoluc
o
n must be taken in counsell.
For otherwise nothing is [[paraphed]] by a Counsellor
but w
at
e Coucell hath resolved.
12. The
Councell of state
is to take order alone
w
t
e advise of
e chief martiall men, for
e establishing of militarie discipline: wherein
e
G
n
rall states
are not to intermedle, nether
doe
ei claime
at prerogative, albeit oftentimes
e states of particular promises geve order in
those affaires, whereby there groweth c
o
fusion
in this government, whiche doth muche offend
e
Councell of State.
fol.174v
Belgia 1590: May
13. The Councell of state hath ever stoode uppon
it, that they will be
[made]
privy
[th. lres]
to
all
intelligences, and have
e disposition of all re-
wardes.
15. If to binde them all in generall and in par-
ticular w
t
one g
n
rall obligac
o
n might suffice,
it would cutt of
the
e
[well]
some
occasion of gelousie, whiche
they
wilbe easely conceaved uppon
e motion of
this Article.
17. It is every mans opinion,
at
e G
n
rall States
will never
[g.]
passe suche an ample com-
mission, but uppon
e particular notice and spe-
cification of suche pointes be free hande. Otherwise
e Deputies of
e States in those maters whereto their
c
o
mission doth extende, does alwaies c
o
ferre w
t
e Councell of state, and
at aswell about the
Contribuc
o
ns, as otherwise as
occasion [serve .]
occasio is
[are]
offered
18. If this clause of exception were omitted, there
would be lesse mater ministred to
e G
n
rall
States of Usurping uppon
e Councell, Whereto
of
em selves
they are
alwaies
over prone of themselves.
19. It is fully c
o
prehended in
e first part of
e former Article.
20. There are sufficient Magasins already erected
and good order taken for provision of victuals
and munition.
fol.175r
Belgia. 1590: May.
22. This
moti
o
will be thought to proceede through
e sug-
gestion of some privat persons, and will
offend them very muche for that it is not
thought reasons
at
so smalle parcels of
Provinces not c
o
tributing
but rather burdensome to
e contrey, should have
any
v
voice or
interest
in
e
in
e direction
of maters
and disposition of
e Contributions
of
and affaires of
e other
other Contreis
Provinces:
in
in so muche as
e
4
principall
Provinces
[.]
at c
o
tribut will [hardly] allowe
can not well [brooke]
at
Gueldres
and every[/sell], although they
be almost full Provinces, should exercise such
autoritie among them.
24. It should seeme to be requisit for divers re s-
pectes, that her Ma
ties
Counsello
rs
or Counsello
r
present should concurre w
t
e L. Generall
in
e Negative.
26. They doe alwaies alleage
at
e charges of
e
contrey, and their state of Navigation can
not be maintened w
t
out this traffique. But
if there might be a mutuall agreement between
her Ma
tie
and them,
at no shippes of any contrey
w
at
soever, shall be suffered to transport suche pro-
hibited provisions into
spaine
and
or
Portugall
&c.
Unles they come first to some partes, whiche
may by consent be assigned aswell in
England
as in these Provinces, and pay suche tolle and
custome as shalbe thought convenient, it is suppo-
sed heere by divers of themselves, that both this
contrey people would be well contented w
t
it,
and a great revenue collected to
e mainte-
nance of
e warres, as
by good demonstration
it may be further
made manifest by good demonstration
explaned
, if her Ma
tie
shalbe
pleased to hearken unto it.
fol.175v
Belgia. 1590: May.
27. The most part of
e shippes of these contreis
although they be of great burden, are un-
fitte to make shippes of warre.
28. It will be very hardly perfourmed in
these contreis where there are no suche soci-
eties and incorportations of c
o
panies as in
England, and in
at respect no ready meanes
to take good order for
e contentac
o
n of the
marchants.
29. Heere is in effect
e
self
same order
already
already
